title: ‘Pro cycling is totally disconnected from the reality of the everyday tool that is a bicycle’: TCR rider Marin de Saint-Exupéry
content:
Cyclist
‘Pro cycling is totally disconnected from the reality of the everyday tool that is a bicycle’: TCR rider Marin de Saint-Exupéry

The Transcontinental Race (TCR), Europe’s most extreme self-supported ultra cycling race, is underway, with over 350 riders heading from Belgium to Greece.

One of those racing is Marin de Saint-Exupéry, a 26-year-old ultra cyclist from Switzerland. Saint-Exupéry is taking on his fourth TCR, and is hoping to improve on his fifth place last year.

Saint-Exupéry, who by day is a bike messenger, has been vocal in encouraging riders to be more conscious of their environmental footprint, and to take trains and boats instead of planes, and in some cases, ride, to races.  

He has used trains and boats to get to and from every TCR he has done so far, and for this year’s TCR Saint-Exupéry caught a train from his home in Lausanne to Brussels and rode 50km to the start line.

Notably, TCR organisers, Lost Dot, introduced a Green Leaderboard and a Low Carbon Travel Fund for TCRno9. 78 riders committed to travelling to and from the race without flying, and Lost Dot offered a £250 grant for 10 riders to make travelling overland more accessible.

Saint-Exupéry is currently head down racing the TCR, but we caught up with him just before he set off.

This is your fourth TCR, why do you keep coming back?

Saint-Exupéry: ‘I’ve progressed every year and I can feel myself getting stronger. This year I want to be at the front of the race with the super strong racers.

‘The first time I did the TCR the goal was to just finish the race, I came second last, about one hour before the time limit. Then I came back to improve my placing and came 17th. Last year I wanted to finish in the front of the race, I had a pretty bad start but managed to close the gap and finish 5th. I’ve progressed every year, and that’s what I’m riding again this year.

Ultra racing is hard enough, why would you ride to an event and then race?

Saint-Exupéry: ‘I like to ride to the start of the race where there is no obvious means of train transport. In Europe the trains are great, and the TCR is a big goal and riding to the race is tiring, so I decided to get a train.

‘When there is no train to get to a race or it would take weeks by train, then it makes a lot of sense to do it my bike. It’s an excuse to have a nice journey. I have discovered that maybe you are more tired when you arrive at the race but you are also more acclimatised to the country. For example when I cycled to the Atlas Mountain Race in Morocco, I was used to Morocco and my stomach was used to the country too. So it was a big bonus.

‘But of course it also depends on the location. I rode to the Silk Road Mountain Race in Kyrgyzstan [and won it] but that is not realistic for 99% of the racers. But for Morocco a few people asked me for tips about getting there by bike. I think it can really help seeing someone do it, and show people it is possible, and doable, you can enjoy it, and you can win it after all that like I did.

‘Every TCR I’ve done I’ve always come by boat and train, it’s always been a super nice memory of being a little group of riders who ride together and share stories about our races. I hope this year there will be a proper big group ride to the boat after the race.’

How do you feel about the TCR introducing a Green Leaderboard and Low Carbon Travel Fund?

Saint-Exupéry: ‘It’s really great that the race organisers are doing the green classification. The TCR is the race which made me fall in love with ultra racing and to see it create these initiatives which are super important makes me really happy. I hope it will encourage more people to cycle to races, to get trains and boats, rather than take an airplane.

‘Even if a few people start doing it, it can change mentalities slowly and encourage other people to ask themselves why they need to fly to a race. Obviously you want to travel the world and discover new things, but it’s important to make people conscious of the carbon footprint of flying and also show that riding to a race is a nice beginning.’

What is your strategy for TCRno9?

Saint-Exupéry: ‘I don’t have a strategy. The goal is to survive the start of the race and then it can only be great.

‘There are a few alternative off-road parcours in this year’s TCR which are shortcuts. They could cost a lot because they are off road but I think I will try them, depending on the weather. I don’t think everyone will do this so it could be useful.

‘I guess the race will be won in less than eight days, so that would be the goal. But it’s always difficult to say in such a long race. If the weather is bad, it can change a lot of things, so we’ll see.’

How do you train for a race like the TCR?

Saint-Exupéry: ‘Because of my day-to-day job as a bike messenger I rack up a lot of kilometres every month but I also train outside of my job.

‘You must train a lot if you want to have success on TCR. I train like a pro athlete would outside of my job with a few adaptations. I have a coach, I do a lot of bikepacking trips to get into the flow of being outside and manage situations which go wrong. The training itself is interval training and a lot of base miles.

‘Every TCR so far I have ridden on a steel bike and this year is no different. I am riding a Fairlight Strael.’

And finally, what do you think about pro cycling and its role in inspiring people to ride bikes?

Saint-Exupéry: ‘I think pro cycling is totally disconnected from the reality of the everyday tool that is a bicycle. It’s not inspiring everyday mobility and I think that’s a shame, as cycling can do so much for this.

‘I was recently at the Wish One Gravel Race in Milau, France. The main sponsor of the event was Total so I had prepared to wear a cycling jersey which said ‘the bike does not need fuel’. I was given the mic and chose to speak about greenwashing in the industry. I think everyone was surprised but it’s super important, cycling deserves so much better.

‘It made me think what a real pro could do if they took the mic and spoke about it. But no one is doing it.’
